qas.question: What are the largest minorities of western Sichuan?
What languages do Tibetans in Sichuan speak?
What language do the Yi people speak?
In what year was the language of the Yi people standardized?
Which University houses one of China's most prominent Tibetology departments?
What are the largest minorities of Southwest University for Nationalities?
What languages do Tibetans in Burma speak?
What language do the Mandarin people speak?
In what year was the language of the Mandarin people standardized?
Which University houses one of China's most prominent Burmese departments?

context: Garzê Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture and Ngawa <b5_0>Tibetan and Qiang<b5_0/> Autonomous Prefecture in western Sichuan are populated by <a0_0>Tibetans and Qiang<a0_0/> people. Tibetans speak the <a1_0><b6_0>Khams and Amdo Tibetan<b6_0/><a1_0/>, which are Tibetic languages, as well as various Qiangic languages. The Qiang speak Qiangic languages and often Tibetic languages as well. The Yi people of Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture in southern Sichuan speak the <a2_0><b7_0>Nuosu<b7_0/><a2_0/> language, which is one of the Lolo-Burmese languages; Yi is written using the Yi script, a syllabary standardized in <a3_0><b8_0>1974<b8_0/><a3_0/>. The <a4_0><b9_0>Southwest University for Nationalities<b9_0/><a4_0/> has one of China's most prominent Tibetology departments, and the Southwest Minorities Publishing House prints literature in minority languages. In the minority inhabited regions of Sichuan, there is bi-lingual signage and public school instruction in non-Mandarin minority languages.
